review_blob: Poured from a 330ml bottle. Pours golden with a slight orange tinge, a white head that went to a light film on top. Huge tropical hop aroma and loads of grapefruit. Taste is massively bitter, lots of grapefruit but with more of a malt backbone than I expected, though its still not huge. The bitterness lingers for a long time ,one thing slightly letting it down is the weakish, quite thin mouthfeel. A pretty one dimensional beer but I love huge, hoppy beers. Would have this again and again, good for the price.

On cask at The White Star in Stoke. Not quite as dark as expected, a very, very dark ruby rather than pitch black, with a tan head. Huge coffee notes on the nose, almost dominating the smell. The taste too is heavily leaning towards coffee, though there are other flavours, some bitterness, roasted malts and some chocolate. Very thick and well bodied as youd expect for a 6% cask ale, a good finish. A step up from their regular stout, a very good beer which should be a permanent addition and perhaps bottled.

660ml bottle from Beers Of Europe, pours almost pitch black with a fluffy tan head that stays. Smell is tons of mango and citrus aswell as plenty of malt. Taste is huge extremely complex, lots of roasted malt, liquorice, some coffee, off set with huge hop bitterness, plenty of grapefruit, citrus and mango. A very long and bitter finish, medium carbonation and medium-full bodied. Absolutely stunning beer, the best black IPA Ive had thus far and possible my favourite beer from possibly my favourite brewery.
beer_name: Stone Sublimely Self Righteous Black IPA

review_blob: 375ml Champagne bottle from Beers Of Europe. Pours a hazy golden colour with some of the yeast in the glass, has a medium sized white head which stays. A very yeasty, earthy smell with hints of lemon. Taste is again very yeasty with a malt backbone, some bitterness on the back of the tongue. Lots of yeast present. Has a long finish and a medium body with a medium level of carbonation. An excellent beer, best saison Ive had so far, though Ive not had many.

330ml bottle from Beers Of Europe poured into a teku glass, pours pretty much pitch black with a thick, fluffy, brown head with lasted. Aroma is plenty of mango and grapefruit but with a good presence of roasted malt. Quite a bitter taste, good roasted malt background, plenty of fruity hop character, again, mango, grapefruit, citrus fruits, but also plenty of darker flavours like liquorice and dark fruits. A nice long bitter finish, medium body and good carbonation, an excellent black IPA, Im becoming a huge fan of the style. Also my favourite Mikkeller beer so far.

Poured from 330ml into Teku glass, pours golden with a fluffy white head that quickly vanished. A lot of the yeast in the smell with some malts. Quite a bitter taste, plenty of yeast, some herbs/spices, you can definitely taste the orange peel. Medium bodied and medium carbonation. Quite an unusual beer, rather nice, glad I tried it, would probably have again.

Poured from a 355ml bottle, pours a typical IPA colour, golden/orange with a thin white head that soon went to a film. Smell is of pine, citrus and mango. Plenty of sweet malt on the taste, maltier than I was expecting, resinous hops, plenty of bitterness, pine, citrus fruits, pineapple and mango. Medium bodied with a long, bitter finish. An excellent and well balanced IPA.

330ml bottle from The Holy Inadequate in Etruria, pours like a classic porter, very dark, though not black, with a dark ruby red coming through at the edges. It has a small, bubbly, tan head. Smell of liquorice and roasted malts. The taste is big, as you would expect, again I got a lot of liquorice, some coffee, roasted malts and dark fruits. Very good mouthfeel, thick, full bodied but also rather smooth, goes down quite easy for a 10.5% ale. Nice lingering finish. An excellent beer and a nice surprise.

This beer is huge in every way. Pours deep brown/red, with a thin off white head that dissipated pretty quickly. Huge malty aroma, caramel, dark fruits, with quite a bit of hop presence too. The taste was of dark fruits, cherry, hoppy bitterness, a lot of fairly sweet malt. The mouthfeel of this is one of its best points, for 11.2% its incredibly smooth, very full bodied, almost syrup like. Leaves a coating in your mouth and the taste lingers in a good way. My favourite Stone beer thus far and one of my favourites full stop.

Poured from a 660ml bottle, beautiful looking beer, a translucent, sunset orange with a thin, slightly off white head. Huge aroma, great example of an IPA, citrus, grapefruit, orange, mango, very fruity. Taste is quiet a lot of bitterness, not as much as I expected, but still a lot, with all the typical fruit flavours. The taste lingers for a long time, the carbonation is medium as is the body. One of the best IPAs out there, though Stones regular IPA is a good competitor.

beer_brewer_name: Schneider Weisse G. Schneider & Sohn GmbH
review_blob: Poured from a 500ml bottle, pours like a weizen, very cloudy, no light passing through with a large, white head. Beautiful aroma of bananas and several spices. The taste matches the aroma, beautiful, full banana flavours, cloves, spices, some sweet malts. Rather smooth and you cant taste the alcohol, though it does give it a relatively full body. Carbonation is quite high. A cracking beer again from Schneider Weisse, one of the best German beers Ive had, on par with Aventinus.

330ml bottle from Beer Emporium in Sandbach, pours very thick and pitch black, like motor oil, with a small brown head. Roasted malts and chocolate in the aroma. Huge taste of dark chocolate and roasted malts, very thick mouthfeel with that leaves an oily feel in the mouth. There is a bitter finish. Excellent imperial stout.
beer_name: Blue Monkey Silverback In The USSR

review_blob: Poured from a 330ml bottle, pours black with some dark ruby visible in the light and a thick, dark brown head. Unusually light for a 10% stout, also unusually light bodied, still medium heavy but not almost oil like others. Aroma is heavily of smoke with some chocolate. Lively carbonation, taste was at first dominated by the smoke. After being left out, the taste matured and a lot of flavours came through, more traditional stout flavours like roasted malts and dark chocolate, with the smoke still being present. An excellent beer, definitely one to take your time with, different from their other Imperial Stouts Ive tried, those being Hel & Verdoemenis and Rasputin.

Pours a very deep red with a brown head, initially quite thick but quite quickly dissipated into a thin head. Smell is loads of caramel and some fruits,smell of rum too. Taste is like a bomb of malts, very powerful, plenty of toffee and caramel flavours, dark fruit flavours, a big burn taste on the back of the mouth, you can tell its aged in whisky casks. Nice and thick on the mouth, I do quite like the burn. Its a good beer definitely, one Id have again if it werent so expensive.
beer_name: BrewDog / Ballast Point San Diego Scotch Ale

review_blob: Pours a deep reddy brown with a fluffy, beige head. Got quite a lot of hops on the nose with the boozy and malty smell youd expect from a barley wine. The taste is beautiful, TONS of thick malt flavours, dark fruits, raisins, caramel, toffee, some hop bitterness, not as much as expected from the smell, but I dont think that takes from the beer. Quite a lot of sweetness to this too from the malts, really, really good. The mouthfeel is very thick, quite oily, coats your mouth, medium to low carbonation. Excellent beer, possibly the best barley wine Ive had yet and possibly my favourite from Ngne .

Pours a very dark ruby red with a beige head, quite thin, plenty of lacing. Smell is overwhelmingly of smoke and burnt wood, amazing smell. Taste is very smokey again, a certain type of smoke though, almost like a smoked cheese or meat. After the smoke, the malts come in, like a dark larger or porter, quite roasty. Also a tiny bit of chocolate on the back of the tongue. Lovely and smooth despite the carbonation, long smokey aftertaste. There are two words to describe this beer: Smoke and amazing.

Pousr a hazy orange colour, like marmalade, with a slightly off white head, which initially was huge. A thin head remained throughout. Plenty of hop bitterness and citrus on the nose. Taste is different, bitter, but less citrus, more of a light tropical fruit taste, some ginger in the aftertaste. Decent level of carbonation, good body to the beer, slightly oily in texture. As said, some ginger on the aftertaste and plenty of bitterness. Good beer.

Pours a deep ruby/brown with a beige head, initially a thick head but dissipated into more of a lininig. You can smell hops, toffee and plenty of sweet malts. Taste is plenty of hop bitterness, pine, caramel with a lovely, strong malt backbone. Loads of bitterness, a little sweet also.  Medium bodied, medium carbonation, long, bitter finish. A fantastic beer, though I think I prefer the standard Arrogant Bastard.

Pours a golden/orange colour with a bubbly, off white head.  Initial piney and fruity smell, along with hops. Plenty of dry hoppiness in the taste, quite a bit of pineapple and mango type flavours, also quite malty for an IPA. Medium bodied with a good amount of carbonation, a long, dry and bitter finish. A good beer, if nothing special.

On cask at The Bird In Hand, Cheadle. Typical golden ale colour, very clear and clean looking with a white head. In the aroma, hops were present, some sweetness and citrus notes. Taste was first of citrus fruits, particularly grapefruit, a good malt background, quite sweet and certainly some good hop bitterness. The hops leave a nice, bitter aftertaste, the taste of grapefruit lingers aswell, medium bodied. A very good session ale, incredibly drinkable, plenty of flavour and not too strong.

Pours a dark ruby colour, like a porter, with a one finger, beige head. Smell of dry hops and some roasty malts. Taste is good, a slightly different take on the black IPA style (at least the ones Ive had,) much less fruity and sweet than expected, much more bitter with a floral hop character, some citrus and plenty of roasted malts. Leaves a dry aftertaste, decent carbonation and a medium body. A very good beer, gets better as you go down the glass.

Poured from a bottle, its a deep orangy/red with a very thin off white head. Smells like a hoppy red ale rather than a bitter, plenty of hops in the smell, slightly fruity,with mangos in there maybe, also some sweet malt. Taste is rather different, an initial bitterness, some earthy malts and some sweetness, then some citrus comes in. Lingering, cankery bitter aftertaste. Low carbonation and medium body. A pleasant beer, if not too special.

Pours a deep red, almost like a red wine colour, with a small, light red/pink head which dissipates. Aroma is a bit of funk, acidity and some cherry and other fruit notes. Taste is very tart and quite sour, some lemon and sharp citrus flavours, I also picked up a very, very slight minty flavour, which was unexpected, also quite earthy. Has a lingering, bitter finish, quite acidic. Very highly carbonated, medium body. An enjoyable beer, not sure lambics in general would be my favourite style but I do enjoy them, maybe I need to get more into them and taste more to appreciate them more.

Pours a cloudy, golden orange, as youd expect with the style, it has a smooth white head that lasts, as you would expect again from a wheat beer. Smells of cloves and some banana. Taste is again of bananas, cloves, some spice notes and the malt background, very well balanced and easy to drink. Well carbonated, decent body and mouthfeel, leaves a nice, slightly dry finish. Very drinkable, would be an excellent session beer.

Pours a browny-orangey-yellow, cannot see through it, with a smooth white head, was large but disspated into a solid half a finger head, love the look of this beer. Some bananas, spice and wheat on the nose, decent smelling beer. Taste of spice, a tiny bit of sweetness, slight citrus flavour, and again, some banana. Lovely and smooth, very drinkable, nice after taste of the wheat malt.  Medium bodied with a medium carbonation.

Very refreshing and something to just drink and session.

2011 vintage at 14.5 ABV. Wow. I was a little unsure as to how Id find this, with the ratings mentioning a heavy bourbon flavour, but its simply amazing. Pours a pitch black, very thick, like oil, has a very small, deep brown head which almost instantly dissipates, there are plenty of alcohol legs. Smell is obviously quite a lot of bourbon with chocolate and roasted malt notes, some alcohol is also present. Simply amazing tasting beer, there is a strong bourbon taste but its not overwhelming, its well balanced but very noticable. Theres also a big dark chocolate taste which coats your mouth, there is a strong roasted malt flavour too. It is quite sweet all ofver the tongue. Has a beautiful bourbon finish with some alcohol burn as it goes down, really warms your chest. Very thick and oily yet smooth, a beautiful mouthfeel.

Simply stunning.

Pours a light amber with a white head. Certainly a very funky smell, some fruity notes, quite a bit of the sourness which I expected to smell. Taste is quite sour and salty, reminds me a lot of champagne, but a more sour, some white wine/white grapes coming through, quite a bit of acidity. The mouthfeel is medium, plenty of carbonation, theres a quite bitter, dry finish on the front of the mouth but with a sour after taste at the back. Complex, full of flavour, definitely something Id have again. Not bad for my first try.

beer_brewer_name: Schneider Weisse G. Schneider & Sohn GmbH
review_blob: Pours a translucent, dark brown colour with a thin, off white head that quickly dissipates. You can smell the alcohol a little, but theres plenty of sweet malts and a smell, sort of like figs or dates. Very sweet tasting, also quite boozy, lots of sweet malt, figs and other dark fruits. Very thick as you would expect for a 12% beer, low carbonation, decent mouth feel with a long lasting finish. A nice beer, maybe a little too strong, not as good as the regular Aventinus.

beer_brewer_name: Schneider Weisse G. Schneider & Sohn GmbH
review_blob: Pours a murky brown colour with a beige head, had to wait a bit for it to die down as it was huge at first. Nice banana smell, with some malt and slight yeasty smell, mostly banana though. Taste is quite strongly of banana, plenty of toffee too, lovely malty flavours, quite a sweet, desserty taste at the back of the mouth, extremely pleasant. Whilst you can tell its quite a big beer, the alcohol is hidden pretty well. Full bodied and thick, lovely sweet aftertaste. Shall have to get more of this!

Pours a very, very clear amber with a thin off-white head, a beautiful looking beer. Smells of malts with some, light hops and dark fruits. Taste is a lot fruitier than your average bitter, somewhat sweet, with a great malt and toffee taste, there is again a hop taste present. Absolutely incredible mouthfeel which is probably my favourite thing about the beer, probably the smoothest beer Ive ever had. Leaves a nice aftertaste, a beer thats so easy to drink youd forget its nearly 6%.

Once again, an absolute stunner from Alesmith. Pours a golden/orange colour, much lighter than expected, medium white head. Big aromas of grapefruit, orange and other citrus fruits, a long with some sweet malt smells. The taste is stunning, again, like their IPA, supremely balanced, loads of hops with the fruits and bitterness, perfectly complimented by a strong malt backbone. A long, bitter finish and a good full body. An excellent beer which I would have on a regular basis if it were easier to get hold of.

Pours a deep ruby/brown with a tan head, which at first is quite thick but soon settles into a thin but consistent head. Lovely smell of citrusy hops and biscuity malt which is a sign of things to come. The taste hits you with the malt, lots of biscuit, caramel, then the hops, with bitterness and quite a lot of citrus notes. Absolutely fantastically balanced. Lovely, well bodied mouthfeel, medium carbonation, leaving a beatiful bitter finish. Excellent, excellent beer.

From a bottle, pours black with a small amount of light coming through, a beige head that quickly dissipates. Smell of roasty malts, chocolate and  a bit of liquorice. Beatiful taste, plenty of liquorice which makes it stand out from the rest with chocolate, roasted malts, a bit of coffee and some creaminess. The liquorice flavour lingers on the tongue and there is also a nice roasty finish, lovely mouthfeel, quite thick, full bodied, medium carbonation. Excellent beer.

Pours black with some light shining through, large, thick, beige head, quite forthy, eventually turns into a very small head with a lot of lacing left on the glass. Arent picking up too much aroma, bit of a musty smell, maybe even a yeasty smell. Nice tasting beer, quite creamy with dark chocolate, plenty of roasted malt and a slight coffee flavour, also quite bitter. Nice mouthfeel, well carbonatonated, medium bodied, lovely cankery finish but nothing too strong. This is the kind of beer that you could drink 5 or 6 of easily, very drinkable, nothing too outstanding.

From a bottle, pours a deep, burnt orange with a thin, off white head. An unusual aroma, quite funky, not a typical IPA aroma, almost a false, chemically smell. Slight bit of fruit and hops in there, but not much. Taste is again unusual, a bit of an unpleasant taste, again, perhaps chemical like, but its soon gone with some nice fruit flavours, a bit of spice and a surprising amount of malt. Feels nice in the mouth, quite thick and smooth, but with that unusual flavour lasting the longest. Cant quite put my finger on what it is, not a bad beer but not one Id be particularly bothered about trying again.

Pours black with some light coming through around the edges, massive, light brown head, wasnt expecting that as it had been just stored for weeks. Couldnt smell too much, possibly because of the head, but there were spices coming through and the typical stout roastiness. The ginger has a very pleasant kick, a nice spiciness to the beer, some chocolate coming through aswell, some roasted malts to compliment it. A long lasting spice on the mouth, medium bodied, medium carbonation. Good beer, not at all unpleasant, but Ive had better.

Poured from a 330ml bottle, this is a serious imperial stout. Pours like oil, very thick, jet black, a very thin light brown head that goes quite quickly. Smell is mostly of coffee with the usual roasted malt and slight chocolate accompanying, definitely coffee dominating though. Big, big taste, lots of chocolate, roasted malts, coffee, slightly sweet, a bit of cankeryness on the back of the tongue. Gorgeous, gorgeous mouthfeel, extremely thick yet smooth, leaving a very pleasant taste that takes ages to go. One of the best Ive tried.

Poured from a 330ml bottle. Pours a deep amber with a bubbly, off-white head. Smell is as youd expect from a strong, darker belgian beer. Plenty of malts and dark fruits, a some spices. The taste is of caramel, spices, malts, plenty of fruit character including green apple which surprised me. Quite full bodied, medium carbonation, went down very well with a lovely smooth finish and a slightly alcoholic feel.

On Cask at The Greyhound, Newcastle Under Lyme. A clear, brown beer with a tan head. Not much to the smell, just a slight malty smell, nothing unpleasant though. Not much to the taste at first either, but after a couple of sips, a pleasant nutiness came through, backed plenty of malts and some slight hop notes. A slightly hoppy finish, very nice, very drinkable beer.

On cask at Euston Tap. Pretty much the little brother of the Imperial Black IPA, as I was expecting. Poured a very, very deep red colour, almost black but with plenty of light penetrating with an off white head. Smells lightly of hops and citrus fruits. Tastes of malts, grapefruit, pineapple and a hoppy bitterness, quite sweet. Lovely hoppy finish, nice mouthfeel, medium bodied, light carbonation. Very good beer, though a notch below Imperial Black IPA..

Bottle bought from BrewDog Manchester. Pours a very dark black, very little carbonation, quite a big, brown head. Smells fruity, mainly grapefruit and mango. Quite a malty start with the citrus fruits coming in soon after, malts continue to the finish which is quite bitter. Thick and oily mouthfeel, a very good beer, though there are better black IPAs out there for a lot less. Not really encouraged to try the Abstrakt series again.

Bottle bought from BrewDog Manchester. The thought of a 17.1% stout from BrewDog did excite me, but I left very, very disappointed, especially considering the price. Pours like oil, completely black, as expected, with little head that quickly disappears completely. Overwhelming smell of alcohol, with some malts and whisky. Started off well, a strong, but quite tasty stout, roasted malts and coffee dominant, then slight whisky notes, but mostly alcohol. Very, very thick as expected, but very alcoholic, too much so. Really spoils this beer, found it incredibly difficult to drink.

Definitely lives up to the hype. Pours like oil, pitch black, very thick with a small dark brown head, typical of a big imperial stout. Strong smell of roasted malts, coffee, chocolate and caramel. Quite a sweet taste with plenty of chocolate, coffee, toffee, some dark fruits and caramel. Very well balanced, beautiful, thick mouthfeel, very smooth. Has a roasty, slightly kankery finish, an excellent imperial stout.

Pours a deep brown with an off white head. Smells of toffee, malts and chocolate. The taste is so much more, there is toffee, some roasted malts, chocolate hints, caramel, good malty bass with a slightl hop presence. The beer seems to coat your mouth and fill every inch with flavour, leaving a malty finish. An excellent beer, a real treat.

From a 500ml bottle, pours black with a tan head, light comes through the edges, making them a very deep red. Smell is not too strong, mostly roasted malts coming through. Taste is dominated by roasted malt and some coffee, with slight chocolate notes. Has a roasty finish, smooth mouth feel, medium bodied. A good beer, if a little overpriced. Too expensive for me to consider having again, a little disappointed after trying their excellent Imperial Brown Ale.

Amazing. 660ml bottle from BrewDog Manchester. Pours a beautiful orange colour with a white head. Strong hop aroma with sweet fruits, orange, grapefruit and possibly mango. Taste is similar but better, fabulously balanced with a malt backbone. A long, bitter finish follows. Great mouthfeel, medium bodied and moderately carbonated. Best IPA I have had.

Hazelnut hits this right on the head. Poured from a 355ml bottle, a deep ruby/brown with a small off white head. Loads of hazelnut on the aroma, with a lot of malt character. Taste is the same, almost like eating nuts, incredible nutty, malty, little bit of caramel. Medium bodied, very smooth with a slightly bitter finish. Soft carbonation, a very good ale.

Pours a dark, ruby red/brownish colour with an off white head which stays somewhat. Lovely smelling beer, loads of malt, raisins and caramel. A beautifully balanced beer, a great, rich malt flavour that lasts, with a biscuit taste, raisins and some very slight spice notes. A superbly smooth mouthfeel, a lovely, bitter finish. A great beer!

Pours a beautiful, dark copper/red colour with a very thin off white head that quickly dissipates, though this is probably because of the dishwasher tablets. Smell of malts, very slight fruity smell. Lovely, rich malty taste with some notes of biscuit and dark fruits. Has a bitter finish which lasts, very smooth to drink. Much, much better than Old Speckled Hen and Old Golden Hen, a pleasant surprise! Fullers 1845 is better though.

Smell of citrus fruit, particularly grapefruit and hops. From cask, between amber and gold in colour with a thin white head. Lovely, fruity taste, grapefruit and slight bit of mango with a strong, dry, bitter finish that lasts. Medium bodied, a very enjoyable beer.
